events.description: US natural gas futures rose almost 5% to $3.46 per million British thermal units on Wednesday.
A severe cold weather event that occurred last week, impacting gas storage levels.
Geopolitical conflict that led to global supply disruptions and increased demand for US LNG.

facts.fact_text: US natural gas futures rose almost 5% to $3.46 per million British thermal units on Wednesday.

evidences.evidence_text: US natural gas futures rose almost 5% to $3.46 per million British thermal units on Wednesday

facts.fact_text: Average gas flows to the eight largest US LNG export terminals rose to 18.3 bcfd in February.

evidences.evidence_text: Average gas flows to the eight largest US LNG export terminals rose to 18.3 bcfd so far in February, up from 17.8 bcfd in January

facts.fact_text: The US became the world’s largest LNG exporter in 2023.

evidences.evidence_text: The US became the world’s largest LNG exporter in 2023 as global demand surged

facts.fact_text: Average gas production in the Lower 48 states was 106.4 bcfd in February.

evidences.evidence_text: Average gas production in the Lower 48 states edged up to 106.4 bcfd in February from 106.3 bcfd in January.

claims.claim_text: Temperatures are expected to be mostly warmer than normal through February 19.

evidences.evidence_text: Temperatures are expected to be mostly warmer than normal through February 19, though the Northeast will remain below average for another week.

claims.claim_text: Heavy withdrawals during the Arctic blast reduced storage from 5% above normal to 1% below normal.
claims.author: Analysts

evidences.evidence_text: Analysts expect that heavy withdrawals during last week’s Arctic blast reduced storage from about 5% above normal to roughly 1% below normal

claims.claim_text: Near-term supply pressures are being maintained.
claims.author: Analysts

evidence.evidence_text: US natural gas futures rose almost 5% to $3.46 per million British thermal units on Wednesday, supported by higher flows to liquefied natural gas export plants.
global demand surged following supply disruptions linked to Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine.
Analysts expect that heavy withdrawals during last week’s Arctic blast reduced storage
